ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about 1000 years of Russian history.
I gained an understanding of the major dynamics and events that shaped around a thousand years of Russian history and culture.
I learned a lot about Russian history and all the rulers
Insights into the development of Russia, trends in Russia over 1000 years and a better understanding of Russian military, civil, religious, and cultural history.

Very comprehensive understanding of the origins of Russian society and government and how they played out into the 18th century. Also learned a great deal of biographical information and understanding surrounding the most prominent Russian characters such as Ivan the Great, Ivan the Terrible, Peter the Great, and Catherine the Great.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was a very good class.

Strengths: amazing lectures, engaging readings, fascinating material 
Weaknesses: none
The strength was the way the professor lectured. He knew so much and each class was like a story
Strengths - fascinating course with a great reading list, a good workload, and an excellent professor. Weaknesses - the final was almost half the grade which may be a concern for some people.

The lectures were pretty boring/ almost too dense to be locked into unless you had a serious passion for medieval Russia. That being said, the books we read/ required readings were an excellent complement to class material. Slide shows/ some mixed media type presentation would have aided lectures greatly

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. There were a lot of readings, but they were all helpful.

Absolutely! This is the best introduction to Russian history that I could have imagined. Prof. Bushkovitch is unbelievably knowledgeable about every aspect of the material and is an amazing lecturer. The course is fascinating and engaging.
Yes! You get a lot out of this course if you show up to lecture and do the readings
Yes, absolutely. All students of history or those interested in Russia should take this class.

Yes. I'm not exactly sure how it happened, but I just left the class with this incredible knowledge of a thousand years of Russian history (and greater European thought) that I didn't have before, which is my barometer for a successful class.

extras.title: HIST 290 01/RSEE 225 01 - Russia from the 9th C to 1801
